words.latinSentence: Legatus epistulam ā senātō accepit.
words.englishSentence: The envoy received the letter from the senate.

words.latinSentence: Aliī servī in castrō laborant, aliī in oppidō habitant.
words.englishSentence: Some slaves work in the camp, while others live in the town.

words.latinSentence: Oppidani novum annum cum spe celebrant.
words.englishSentence: The townspeople celebrate the new year with hope.

words.latinSentence: Milites circum oppidum mūrōs ambulant.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers walk around the town’s walls.

words.latinSentence: Consul clārus virtutibus et sapientiā laudātur.
words.englishSentence: The consul is famed for his virtues and wisdom.

words.latinSentence: Miles dīligentis disciplinae magnum studium habet.
words.englishSentence: The hardworking soldier shows great dedication to discipline.

words.latinSentence: Via ad castrum dūra et fatigosa est.
words.englishSentence: The road to the camp is harsh and tiring.

words.latinSentence: Milites ad fōntem oppidī aquam capiunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers draw water from the fountain in the town.

words.latinSentence: Nuntius gravis de hostibus ad castra missus est.
words.englishSentence: A serious message about the enemies was sent to the camp.

words.latinSentence: Ad hōram sextam, cives in foro conveniunt.
words.englishSentence: At the sixth hour, the citizens gather in the market.

words.latinSentence: Legatus milites iubet ad castra redeundum.
words.englishSentence: The envoy orders the soldiers to return to the camp.

words.latinSentence: Imperator maximē exsultat post victoriam.
words.englishSentence: The emperor rejoices very greatly after the victory.

words.latinSentence: Morbus per castra celeriter diffunditur.
words.englishSentence: Illness spreads quickly through the camp.

words.latinSentence: Nūper milites ad castra redierunt.
words.englishSentence: Recently, the soldiers returned to the camp.

words.latinSentence: Cives iter faciunt ad oppidum magnum.
words.englishSentence: The citizens make a journey to the great town.

words.latinSentence: Taberna oppidī plēna est cibīs et vinō.
words.englishSentence: The town’s shop is full of food and wine.

words.latinSentence: Magister dicit: 'Plūs discite quam ludite.'
words.englishSentence: The teacher says: 'Learn more than you play.'

words.latinSentence: Militibus praemium honoris datum est.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers were given a reward of honor.

words.latinSentence: Senex sapiēns consilia gravia dat cīvibus.
words.englishSentence: The wise old man gives serious advice to the citizens.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus quaerit: 'Unde venīt nuntius iste?'
words.englishSentence: The student asks: 'From where does this messenger come?'

words.latinSentence: Sub caelo sereno, milites iter faciunt.
words.englishSentence: Under the clear sky, the soldiers make their journey.

words.latinSentence: Milites in silva arma cēlunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers hide their weapons in the forest.

words.latinSentence: Cives cōnfīdunt duci, quoniam prudentiam habet.
words.englishSentence: The citizens trust the leader because he has wisdom.

words.latinSentence: Post conventum, dux castra ēgressus est.
words.englishSentence: After the meeting, the leader went out of the camp.

words.latinSentence: Puer pila in arenam iacit.
words.englishSentence: The boy throws the ball into the sand.

words.latinSentence: Nova expeditiō incipitur ab imperātōre.
words.englishSentence: A new expedition is begun by the commander.

words.latinSentence: Dux īnfēlīx casum in proelio passus est.
words.englishSentence: The leader suffered an unlucky mishap in battle.

words.latinSentence: Milites ingressi oppidum intraverunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers, having entered, went into the town.

words.latinSentence: Dux cōnspicātus hostium formam, consilium ceperit.
words.englishSentence: The leader, having caught sight of the enemy formation, took counsel.

words.latinSentence: Magister moneō discipulōs ne tardent.
words.englishSentence: The teacher warns the students not to be late.

words.english: turns a statement into a question
words.latinSentence: Venisne ad castra hodie?
words.englishSentence: Are you coming to the camp today?

words.latinSentence: Dux praebet consilium militibus in proelio.
words.englishSentence: The leader provides advice to the soldiers in battle.

words.latinSentence: Mulier, precāta de pace, in templum venit.
words.englishSentence: The woman, having prayed for peace, came to the temple.

words.latinSentence: Exercitus prōgressus in fines hostium penetravit.
words.englishSentence: The army, having advanced, penetrated into enemy territory.

words.latinSentence: Quīdam vir nobilis oppidī dux factus est.
words.englishSentence: A certain noble man became the leader of the town.

words.latinSentence: Quō modō hostēs castra oppugnant?
words.englishSentence: In what way do the enemies attack the camp?

words.latinSentence: Milites, regressi ex proelio, fatigati erant.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers, having returned from battle, were weary.

words.latinSentence: Cives simul in forum congregantur.
words.englishSentence: The citizens gather together in the marketplace.

words.latinSentence: Dux talem disciplinam in castrō instauravit.
words.englishSentence: The leader established such discipline in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Magister verbum novum discipulis docuit.
words.englishSentence: The teacher taught the new word to the students.

words.latinSentence: Miles adiuvō sociōs in castrō.
words.englishSentence: The soldier helps his comrades in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Sacerdos super āram in templo preces facit.
words.englishSentence: The priest offers prayers at the altar in the temple.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus studet; autem ludere etiam vult.
words.englishSentence: The student studies; but he also wants to play.

words.latinSentence: Milites hostibus cēdērunt post arduum proelium.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers gave way to the enemies after a difficult battle.

words.latinSentence: Dux cōnspicātus hostium formam, consilium ceperit.
words.englishSentence: The leader, having caught sight of the enemy formation, took counsel.

words.latinSentence: Mater magna cūrā filios in oppidō alit.
words.englishSentence: The mother cares greatly for her children in the town.

words.latinSentence: Artifex opus difficile efficit in officinā oppidī.
words.englishSentence: The craftsman accomplishes a difficult work in the town workshop.

words.latinSentence: Faber in oppidō aedificia pulchra struit.
words.englishSentence: The craftsman builds beautiful buildings in the town.

words.latinSentence: Vir ingenium habet in arte gubernandi.
words.englishSentence: The man has talent in the art of governing.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli lentē discunt verba nova.
words.englishSentence: The students slowly learn new words.

words.latinSentence: Statua maior in foro omnibus conspicuit.
words.englishSentence: The larger statue in the forum was conspicuous to all.

words.latinSentence: Imperator mandātum firmum militibus dedit.
words.englishSentence: The emperor gave a firm order to the soldiers.

words.latinSentence: Dux novum modum proelii in castrō instituit.
words.englishSentence: The leader instituted a new method of combat in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Nūntius celeriter nuntia de pace portat.
words.englishSentence: The messenger quickly carries news of peace.

words.latinSentence: Milites pāreunt duci in proelio.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers obey the leader in battle.

words.latinSentence: Cives putant ducem sapientem esse.
words.englishSentence: The citizens think that the leader is wise.

words.latinSentence: Dux hostem rapiit in proelio improvīs.
words.englishSentence: The leader seized the enemy in battle with a sudden move.

words.latinSentence: Fur scelestus in oppidō latuit.
words.englishSentence: The wicked thief hid in the town.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus scit multa de antiquis moribus.
words.englishSentence: The student knows much about ancient customs.

words.latinSentence: Cives vestīmenta elegāntia in foro gerunt.
words.englishSentence: The citizens wear elegant clothes in the market.

words.latinSentence: Dux arcessit amīcum in castrum ut consilium daret.
words.englishSentence: The leader sent for a friend to give advice in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Imperator auctōritātem suam in proelio manifestāvit.
words.englishSentence: The emperor demonstrated his authority in battle.

words.latinSentence: Hostis captus in carcer reclusus est.
words.englishSentence: The captured enemy was confined in prison.

words.latinSentence: Miles comes fidelis in expeditione mansit.
words.englishSentence: The soldier’s loyal companion remained on the expedition.

words.latinSentence: Legatus hostem in castrō comprehendit cum celeritate.
words.englishSentence: The envoy seized the enemy in the camp quickly.

words.latinSentence: Cum sol occidit, castra parata sunt ad quietem.
words.englishSentence: When the sun set, the camp was prepared for rest.

words.latinSentence: Milites dēscendunt ex acie ad iter per silvam.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers come down from the heights to march through the forest.

words.latinSentence: Arma in terra humī reponuntur post proelium.
words.englishSentence: The weapons are placed on the ground after the battle.

words.latinSentence: Intereā, dux in urbe novas leges promulgavit.
words.englishSentence: Meanwhile, the leader proclaimed new laws in the city.

words.latinSentence: Oppidum, quamquam minor, multum decora est.
words.englishSentence: The town, although smaller, is very beautiful.

words.latinSentence: Milites moventur ad arcem in itinere.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers move toward the citadel on their march.

words.latinSentence: In proelio, milites neque metum neque cladem patiuntur.
words.englishSentence: In battle, the soldiers suffer neither fear nor defeat.

words.latinSentence: Milites, passīs periculīs, ad castra redierunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers, having suffered dangers, returned to the camp.

words.latinSentence: Imperator retineō hostes ne plūs accedant.
words.englishSentence: The emperor held back the enemies so that they would not advance further.

words.latinSentence: Hostēs saevī in proelio impetum fecerunt.
words.englishSentence: The savage enemies launched an attack in battle.

words.latinSentence: Milites ducem secūtī in acie incesserunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers, having followed the leader, advanced in the line.

words.latinSentence: Castra sub montibus locata sunt.
words.englishSentence: The camp is located beneath the mountains.

words.latinSentence: Ultimus proelii dies memorābilis fuit.
words.englishSentence: The final day of the battle was memorable.

words.latinSentence: Magister vērum loquitur, ut discipuli discant.
words.englishSentence: The teacher speaks the truth so that the students may learn.

words.latinSentence: Vultus militum, anxius sed constans, in acie patebat.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers’ faces, anxious yet determined, were evident on the front.

words.latinSentence: Aliquis in castrō latuit post noctem.
words.englishSentence: Someone hid in the camp after nightfall.

words.latinSentence: Dux ostium castrī aperit ad milites intrandō.
words.englishSentence: The leader opens the camp gate for the soldiers to enter.

words.latinSentence: Disputatio inter ducem et senatorum fuit brevis sed intensa.
words.englishSentence: The debate between the leader and the senators was short but intense.

words.latinSentence: Captīvus in castrō servatur.
words.englishSentence: The captive is kept in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Castra prope flumen situata sunt ad ripam colli.
words.englishSentence: The camp is situated near the river on the hillside.

words.latinSentence: Imperator milites cōgit ut castra opus efficant.
words.englishSentence: The emperor compels the soldiers to build the camp.

words.latinSentence: Milites pugnant contrā hostes in campo.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers fight against the enemies in the field.

words.latinSentence: Dignitās imperii in rebus publicīs magni aestimatur.
words.englishSentence: The dignity of the empire is highly valued in public affairs.

words.latinSentence: Senatus ēligit ducem novum in proelio.
words.englishSentence: The senate chose a new leader for the battle.

words.latinSentence: Hīc locus pacis et ordinis est in castrō.
words.englishSentence: Here is the place of peace and order in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Labor diurnus in castrō multis cives implicat.
words.englishSentence: The daily work in the camp involves many citizens.

words.latinSentence: Dux captīvos, si fortūna favet, līberō facere vult.
words.englishSentence: The leader wants to free the captives if fortune favors him.

words.latinSentence: Dux mālle pacem quam bellum optat.
words.englishSentence: The leader prefers peace rather than war.

words.latinSentence: Minimus numerus militum ad proelium sufficit.
words.englishSentence: A very small number of soldiers is enough for the battle.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus nesciō quid in proelio futurum sit.
words.englishSentence: The student does not know what will happen in the battle.

words.latinSentence: Nulla victoria fiet nisi milites fortiter pugnant.
words.englishSentence: There will be no victory unless the soldiers fight bravely.

words.latinSentence: Oculus acutus hostium castra intuebitur.
words.englishSentence: A sharp eye watches over the enemy camp.

words.latinSentence: Poena gravis in lege imperii statuitur.
words.englishSentence: A severe punishment is established by the law of the empire.

words.latinSentence: Qui legem violat, poenās dare debet.
words.englishSentence: He who breaks the law must pay the penalty.

words.latinSentence: Numquam hostēs in proelio pacem quaerent.
words.englishSentence: The enemies will never seek peace in battle.

words.latinSentence: Dux vīvus in castrō honoratus est.
words.englishSentence: The leader, alive, was honored in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Amor inter cives pacem et concordiam fovet.
words.englishSentence: Love among the citizens fosters peace and harmony.

words.latinSentence: Hostēs, in nocte furtivā, provisiōnēs auferunt.
words.englishSentence: The enemies, in a stealthy night, carry off provisions.

words.latinSentence: Bellum inter cives et hostēs longum et ferociter geritur.
words.englishSentence: The war between the citizens and the enemies is long and fiercely fought.

words.latinSentence: Milites commōtī sunt audīre nuntium de imminente bello.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers are alarmed to hear the news of the impending war.

words.latinSentence: Magister milites de arte belli doceō.
words.englishSentence: The teacher instructs the soldiers in the art of war.

words.latinSentence: Dum sol occidit, castra in quiete student.
words.englishSentence: While the sun sets, the camp prepares for rest.

words.latinSentence: Lēgātus Romanus ad provinciam iter facit.
words.englishSentence: The Roman envoy journeys to the province.

words.latinSentence: Legiō audax adversus hostēs pugnat.
words.englishSentence: The brave legion fights against the enemies.

words.latinSentence: Cives magnopere laetantur ob pacem.
words.englishSentence: The citizens are very much delighted by peace.

words.latinSentence: Imperator nōtus est propter sapientiam et fortitudinem.
words.englishSentence: The emperor is well known for his wisdom and strength.

words.latinSentence: Num cives de pace consentiunt?
words.englishSentence: Do the citizens agree about peace?

words.latinSentence: Dux patefecit consilium belli in epistola.
words.englishSentence: The leader revealed the plan of war in a letter.

words.latinSentence: Quantus hostium exercitus in campo apparuit?
words.englishSentence: How great was the enemy army that appeared on the field?

words.latinSentence: Quot milites in legiō subsistunt?
words.englishSentence: How many soldiers are there in the legion?

words.latinSentence: Praeco nuntium belli referō ad urbem.
words.englishSentence: The herald brings back the news of war to the city.

words.latinSentence: Sī pax manet, cives laeti erunt.
words.englishSentence: If peace remains, the citizens will be happy.

words.latinSentence: Testis fidus belli in proelio versātus est.
words.englishSentence: A loyal witness was present in the battle.

words.latinSentence: Dux imperat ut omnes consociātī sint.
words.englishSentence: The leader commands that all be united.

words.latinSentence: Milites vestrī in proelio fortiter pugnant.
words.englishSentence: Your soldiers fight bravely in battle.

words.latinSentence: Virtūs militum in proelio exemplum dat cīvibus.
words.englishSentence: The courage of the soldiers sets an example for the citizens.

words.latinSentence: Milites adeō fortēs in proelio sunt.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers are so brave in battle.

words.latinSentence: Animus ducis milites ad victoriam incitat.
words.englishSentence: The leader’s spirit inspires the soldiers to victory.

words.latinSentence: Arma lucida in sole fulgent in castrō.
words.englishSentence: The shining weapons gleam in the sun in the camp.

words.latinSentence: Cōpiae exercitus in acie ordinatae sunt.
words.englishSentence: The army’s troops are arranged in formation.

words.latinSentence: Exercitus Romanus hostibus fortiter pugnat.
words.englishSentence: The Roman army fights bravely against the enemies.

words.latinSentence: Cives gaudent de pace post longum bellum.
words.englishSentence: The citizens rejoice at the peace after a long war.

words.latinSentence: Gēns Romana clarā et fortiā insignita est.
words.englishSentence: The Roman people are distinguished by their fame and strength.

words.latinSentence: Hostis periculosus fines nostrōs oppugnat.
words.englishSentence: The dangerous enemy attacks our borders.

words.latinSentence: Dux imperat ut milites in acie constanter pugnent.
words.englishSentence: The leader commands that the soldiers fight steadily in the line.

words.latinSentence: Milites incendunt castra hostium in impetu.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers set the enemy camp on fire in an assault.

words.latinSentence: Murus castrī lātus et robustus est.
words.englishSentence: The camp’s wall is wide and sturdy.

words.latinSentence: Exercitus hostium opprimō et celeriter vincit.
words.englishSentence: The army crushes the enemy and wins quickly.

words.latinSentence: Milites oppugnant fortiter castra hostium.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers attack the enemy camp fiercely.

words.latinSentence: Cives ōrant imperatōrem ut pacem concedat.
words.englishSentence: The citizens beg the leader to grant peace.

words.latinSentence: Prīmō, milites in proelio convenērunt.
words.englishSentence: At first, the soldiers gathered for battle.

words.latinSentence: Milites pugnant propter libertatem et honōrem.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers fight on account of freedom and honor.

words.latinSentence: Hostis, proximus finibus nostrīs, appropinquat.
words.englishSentence: The enemy, nearest to our borders, approaches.

words.latinSentence: Quālis exercitus potest vincere hostem?
words.englishSentence: What sort of army can defeat the enemy?

words.latinSentence: Tantus numerus militum in acie praestat ordinem.
words.englishSentence: Such a great number of soldiers provides order in the line.

words.latinSentence: Tot cives in urbe congregati sunt ad celebrandum pacem.
words.englishSentence: So many citizens have gathered in the city to celebrate peace.

words.latinSentence: Milites ac duces in proelio unum consilium habent.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers and commanders have a united plan in battle.

words.latinSentence: Dux cōnstituit castra in loco apto.
words.englishSentence: The leader decided to set up camp in a suitable place.

words.latinSentence: Corpus exercitus in acie apparuit.
words.englishSentence: The body of the army appeared in formation.

words.latinSentence: Fidēs cīvitātis in duce firmiter manet.
words.englishSentence: The loyalty of the state firmly remains with the leader.

words.latinSentence: Fortē, milites nūntium incognitum receperunt.
words.englishSentence: By chance, the soldiers received an unexpected message.

words.latinSentence: Dux ignārus de hostium consiliō non potuit decernere.
words.englishSentence: The leader, unaware of the enemy’s plan, could not decide.

words.latinSentence: Ira imperātōris, tam intensa, milites movebat.
words.englishSentence: The commander’s intense anger stirred the soldiers.

words.latinSentence: Actus malus hostium in proelio periculum creavit.
words.englishSentence: The wicked act of the enemies created danger in the battle.

words.latinSentence: Metus in proelio saepe adversos eventus adfert.
words.englishSentence: Fear in battle often brings adverse outcomes.

words.latinSentence: Multō numerō milites in proelio adveniunt.
words.englishSentence: A great number of soldiers arrive in battle.

words.latinSentence: Milites hostem occīdunt in acie proelio.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers kill the enemy in the battle line.

words.latinSentence: Opēs regni in fiscō acriter servantur.
words.englishSentence: The wealth of the kingdom is carefully guarded in the treasury.

words.latinSentence: Profectus exercitus ex castris celeriter fuit.
words.englishSentence: The army’s departure from the camp was swift.

words.latinSentence: Non timet dux quicquam in proelio hostili.
words.englishSentence: The leader fears nothing in hostile battle.

words.latinSentence: Rēgnum magnum in imperiō celebratur.
words.englishSentence: A great kingdom is celebrated in the empire.

words.latinSentence: Scelus hostium in proelio reprehenditur.
words.englishSentence: The enemy’s crime is condemned in battle.

words.latinSentence: Milites sīc parati sunt ad pugnam.
words.englishSentence: The soldiers are thus ready for combat.

words.latinSentence: Spēs pacis in cīvibus renascitur post bella.
words.englishSentence: The hope for peace is reborn among the citizens after war.

words.latinSentence: Dux dixit ut cives semper virtutem colligant.
words.englishSentence: The leader said that the citizens should always cherish virtue.

words.latinSentence: Victōria in proelio omnibus laetitiam afferit.
words.englishSentence: Victory in battle brings joy to all.

words.latinSentence: ūnus miles in acie praestat.
words.englishSentence: One soldier stands out in the line.

words.latinSentence: Duo duces castra in duobus locīs constituerunt.
words.englishSentence: Two leaders established camps in two places.

words.latinSentence: Trēs cives ad forum conveniunt.
words.englishSentence: Three citizens meet in the market.

words.latinSentence: Quatuuor milites in proelio pariter pugnant.
words.englishSentence: Four soldiers fight equally in battle.

words.latinSentence: Quīnque nuntii celeriter per urbem currunt.
words.englishSentence: Five messengers run quickly through the city.

words.latinSentence: Sex milites in acie ordinantur.
words.englishSentence: Six soldiers are arranged in the line.

words.latinSentence: Septem cives epistulam legunt.
words.englishSentence: Seven citizens read the letter.

words.latinSentence: Octō equī in itinere ad oppidum currunt.
words.englishSentence: Eight horses run on the journey to the town.

words.latinSentence: Novem tabernae in foro invenīuntur.
words.englishSentence: Nine shops are found in the market.

words.latinSentence: Decem discipuli in schola discunt.
words.englishSentence: Ten students study in school.

words.latinSentence: Vīgintī milites in legiō servantur.
words.englishSentence: Twenty soldiers serve in the legion.

words.latinSentence: Triginta cives in consilio congregantur.
words.englishSentence: Thirty citizens gather in the council.

words.latinSentence: Quadrāgintā nūntii per urbem cursant.
words.englishSentence: Forty messengers run through the city.

words.latinSentence: Quīnquāgintā equī in agrum ducuntur.
words.englishSentence: Fifty horses are led into the field.

words.latinSentence: Sexāgintā milites in acie ordinantur.
words.englishSentence: Sixty soldiers are arranged in the line.

words.latinSentence: Septuāgintā cives in foro congregati sunt.
words.englishSentence: Seventy citizens have gathered in the market.

words.latinSentence: Octōgintā castra per agros distributa sunt.
words.englishSentence: Eighty camps are distributed across the fields.

words.latinSentence: Nōnāgintā equī in prātio pascuntur.
words.englishSentence: Ninety horses are grazing in the meadow.

words.latinSentence: Centum milites in proelio fortiter pugnant.
words.englishSentence: One hundred soldiers fight bravely in battle.

words.latinSentence: Mīlle cives in urbe colliguntur.
words.englishSentence: A thousand citizens are gathered in the city.

words.latinSentence: Mīlia equōrum in agrō pascuntur.
words.englishSentence: Thousands of horses graze in the field.
